Text: God presides in the great assembly; He renders judgment among the “gods”:
Context: The psalm opens with a depiction of God's sovereignty and authority over all, including the divine council or assembly of beings sometimes understood as gods or mighty ones.

Text: “How long will you defend the unjust and show partiality to the wicked? Selah
Context: Here, God is addressing the rulers or judges, rebuking them for their injustice and partiality towards the wicked.

Text: Defend the cause of the weak and fatherless; uphold the rights of the afflicted and oppressed.
Context: This verse contains a divine command to protect and advocate for the vulnerable and marginalized in society.

Text: Rescue the weak and needy; deliver them from the hand of the wicked.
Context: Continues the theme of the previous verse, emphasizing the responsibility to act on behalf of those who cannot defend themselves.

Text: They do not know or understand; they wander in darkness. All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
Context: Speaks to the ignorance and lack of understanding among the rulers, which has profound consequences, causing instability in the very foundations of order.

Text: I have said, 'You are “gods”; you are all sons of the Most High.'
Context: God reminds the rulers of their privileged position and past declaration, implying that they should act in accordance with their high calling.

Text: But like men you will die, and fall like any prince.
Context: Despite their position, the rulers are mortal and will face the same judgment as others, falling from their high places.

Text: Arise, O God, judge the earth, for all the nations belong to You.
Context: The psalm concludes with a call for God to take up judgment and rule, recognizing God's sovereignty over all nations.
